name: Google Maps
title: Google Maps

children.text: With Google Maps modules in Make, you can search for places or get directions, location, elevation, roads, or static map images in your Google Maps account.
To use the Google Maps modules, you must have a Google account and billing enabled in the
. You can create an account at
for a list of available endpoints.
To establish the connection, you must:

data.overridedLabel: Establish the connection with Google Maps in Make.

children.text: Create and configure a Google Cloud Platform project for Google Maps
Before you establish the connection in Make, you must create and configure a project in the Google Cloud Platform to obtain your API key.
Your Google account must have Cloud Billing set up in order to enable the required APIs in your project. For information regarding how to create and manage Cloud Billing, see
Google's Manage your Cloud Billing account guide
Create a Google Cloud Platform project for Google Maps
To create a Google Cloud Platform project:
In the top menu, check if your new project is selected in the
dropdown. If not, select the project you just created.
To create a new project or work in the existing one, you need to have the
permission. If you don’t have this permission, ask the Google Cloud Platform Project Owner or Project IAM Admin to grant it to you.
Open the left navigation menu and go to
For more information on Google Web Service APIs, refer to the
Click on the relevant API, then click
Obtain your Google Maps API key
value shown and store it in a safe place.
You will use this value in the
Establish the connection with Google Maps in Make

Log in to your Make account, add a Google Maps module to your
field, enter a name for the connection.

If prompted, authenticate your account and confirm access.
You have successfully established the connection. You can now edit your
and add more Google Maps modules. If your connection requires reauthorization at any point, follow the connection renewal steps
After connecting the app, you can perform the following actions:
If you enter an address, the service geocodes the string and converts it to a latitude/longitude coordinate to calculate directions:
If you enter coordinates, they are used unchanged to calculate directions. Ensure that no space exists between the latitude and longitude values:
Place IDs must be prefixed with
. You can retrieve place IDs from the Get a Location module and the Search for Places module. For more about place IDs, see the
Plus codes must be formatted as a global code or a compound code. Format plus codes as shown here (plus signs are URL-escaped to %2B and spaces are URL-escaped to
is a 4-character area code and a 6-character or longer local code (
is a 6-character or longer local code with an explicit location (CWC8+R9 Mountain View, CA, USA is
- Enter the address, textual latitude/longitude value, or place ID to which you wish to calculate directions. The options for the
are the same as for the

- Enter the desired time of departure or arrival. You can specify the time using one of the options from the supported date and time formats list. Alternatively, you can specify a value of now, which sets the departure time to the current time (correct to the nearest second). Applies when the Transit or Driving option is selected in the Travel Mode field.
, enter the time to determine whether or not Daylight Savings should be applied, based on the time zone of the location.
If you enter an address, the service geocodes the string and converts it to a latitude/longitude coordinate to calculate directions:
If you enter coordinates, they are used unchanged to calculate directions. Ensure that no space exists between the latitude and longitude values:
Place IDs must be prefixed with place_id:. You can retrieve place IDs from the Get a Location module and the Search for Places module. For more about place IDs, see the

Enter the address, textual latitude/longitude value, or place ID to which you wish to calculate directions. The options for the
are the same as for the

- Enter the desired time of departure or arrival. You can specify the time using one of the options from the supported date and time formats list. Alternatively, you can specify a value of now, which sets the departure time to the current time (correct to the nearest second). Applies when the Transit or Driving option is selected in the Travel Mode field.
Note: The Speed Limit service is available to all customers with an Asset Tracking license. For
customers who transitioned to pay-as-you-go pricing, the feature remains active.
trigger allows you to get the local time for any location on earth, for any date in the past. The trigger returns two elements:
the time zone offset from UTC (in seconds) and
the offset for the daylight-savings time from UTC (in seconds).
To get the current local time of a given location, you need to calculate the sum of both values. However, the result refers to the
. To translate the UTC to your local time, you need to add or subtract the time zone difference between UTC and your location.
For example, let's say, you are in Prague and you want to know the current local time (9.6.2014) in New York. The trigger

returns the Time zone offset from UTC -18000 and the Daylight Savings offset from UTC 3600. The sum of both values is -14400 seconds which is -4 hours from UTC. The result you get when repeating the same steps for Prague is +2 hours from UTC. The time difference between Prague and New York is +6 hours.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
